Award.AwardTitle: Catalysis of Microstructure Evolution in Block Copolymer Blend Materials Through Dynamic Modulation of Filler/Matrix Interactions
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

Block copolymers are materials that are capable of self-organizing into a hierarchy of functional nanostructures that are of technological relevance in applications ranging from polymer membranes for next-generation lithium ion batteries to high-performance polymer photovoltaics. The goal of this project is to develop processes to control the formation of defects in these nanostructures, a key requirement for the future technological exploitation of block copolymer based materials. The ultimate goal is to establish procedures that will allow the efficient and economically viable fabrication of block copolymer materials with precisely controlled nanostructure and properties. The program will enhance the teaching of two polymer classes and provide training for one graduate and several undergraduate researchers in the critical area of polymer and nanoscale materials. Ongoing collaborations with educators at Florida A&M University as well as Carnegie Mellon will be leveraged to support the participation of minority students and to engage high school students in materials engineering. Finally, a novel educational interface will be developed for 'hands-on' exploration of materials physics concepts as a means to engage and attract middle and high school students to the study of science and engineering.


TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

The objective of this research program is to understand the implications of filler-matrix interactions on the microstructure evolution in bulk block copolymers and to test the hypothesis that the dynamic modulation of filler-matrix interactions provides a means to increase the rate of grain coarsening. In a first part the project will be focused on the synthesis of a range of homopolymer and polymer-grafted nanoparticle model systems that will facilitate the elucidation of the effect of filler-matrix interactions on the microstructure evolution process in block copolymer blend materials. In a second part, the project will establish the coarsening kinetics and evolution of grain boundary structures in block copolymer/homopolymer blend systems in which the homopolymer favorably interacts with the host copolymer domain. A parallel series of corresponding block copolymer/nanoparticle blend systems will be pursued to identify the role of filler-matrix interaction on the segregation of fillers within boundary regions. In a third part, the program will explore the effect of temperature-cycling to dynamically (and reversibly) 'switch' the interaction between filler and copolymer host domain from 'athermal' to 'miscible'. The objective is to test whether the dynamic modulation of filler-matrix interactions provides a means to energetically destabilize grain boundary defects and hence raise the driving pressure for grain growth. The research plan will be enhanced by collaboration with expert groups in the areas of polymer synthesis and simulation who will provide access to model material systems and support the interpretation of data.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the third year of this project the research focus was on (i) the characterization of grain size evolution in block copolymer/homopolymer blends by ultra-small angle neutron scattering and (ii) the establishing of mechanical as well as thermodynamic models to rationalize the dependence of grain boundary energy on the fraction of segregated homopolymer in grain boundary structures. Outreach and broader impact activities were centered on the completion of an interface allowing the ‘simulation of mechanical properties’of elastomers using a commercially available force feedback joystick as well as the teaching of a course on Nanotechnology to high school students as part of the university’s AP/EA program. 

 

(1) Development of a thermodynamic model to understand the equilibrium concentration of fillers in grain boundary interfaces

 A continuum mechanical model was developed to relate the perturbation of polymer chains to the geometric perturbation of domain size that is associated with defect formation. From the change in chain extension the free energy penalty per chain associated with the boundary formation can be estimated. The primary image depicts the result for the stored elastic energy in symmetric tilt grain boundary defects in a PS-PI block copolymer with a molecular weight of the respective blocks of 50 kg/mol. The results obtained on the basis of this continuum analysis are in excellent agreement with results from self-consistent field simulations (by Matsen, University of Waterloo). A manuscript summarizing the role of grain misorientation on the energy of grain boundary defects and the associated kinetics of filler distribution is currently in preparation.

 

Secondary Research Accomplishments 

Several other secondary projects were performed during the course of the funded period that complemented the research performed in the main thrust. These secondary projects were largely devoted to the better understanding of phase separation in polymer and polymer/particle blend systems. In the following select accomplishments are highlighted.

(2)  Analysis of Interactions and Phase Separation in Polymer Tethered Particle Mixtures(Science Advances, 2016, e1601484) (Figure 2)

(3) Polymerization-induced self-assembly of acrylonitrile via ICAR/ATRP (Macromolecules (2016), 49, 8605–8615 and Polymer 125, (2017), 57-67) (Figure 3)

(4)  Entropy-driven segregation of polymer-grafted nanoparticles under confinement (PNAS (2017), 114, 2462-2467. (Figure 4)

 

Publications during July 16 – June 17 reporting period: 

Ferebee, R., et al. (2016).  Journal of Physical Chemistry B120(20): 4591-4599.

Mahoney, C., et al. (2016).  Polymer93: 72-77.

Schmitt, M., et al. (2016).  Faraday Discussions186: 17-30.

Schmitt, M., et al. (2016).  Science Advances2(12).

Wang, G., et al. (2016).  Macromolecules49(22): 8605-8615.

Wang, G. W., et al. (2017).  Polymer129: 57-67.

Wang, Z. Y., et al. (2017).  Acs Applied Materials & Interfaces9(8): 7515-7522.

Xie, G. J., et al. (2016).  Polymer98: 481-486.

Zhang, R., et al. (2016).  Macromolecules49(10): 3965-3974.

Zhang, R., et al. (2017).  Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America114(10): 2462-2467.

 

Broader impact activities during the July 16 – June 17 reporting period 

 

(1)  Participation at the National Engineers Week at Carnegie Science Center 

Students of the PIs group participated in the annual science outreach program ‘National Engineers Day’ that was being held at the Carnegie Science Center in Pittsburgh on Feb 23-25, 2017. Students of the PIs did contribute to a ‘Chemical and Materials Engineering Booth’ in which a variety of demonstrations were given on the subject of polymer materials.  

 

(2) Teaching of Summer Class on ‘Introduction to Nanoscience and Technology’ to Highschool Students

The PI continued his involvement in the AP/EA Summer program that is being organized by the School of Humanities as well as the Mellon College of Science at Carnegie Mellon University. As part of the program, short courses are being offered to visiting high school student who participate in the university’s AP/EA program.  In 2017, 12 students participated in the class. Seven students who participated in the class continued to pursue engineering studies - one student (Jason Pestaro) joined the Materials Science and Engineering Department in 2018.

 

(3) Development of a ‘Rubber Emulator’ Using Entry-Level Force Feedback Devices

The PI has been continuing a long term educational project in which we aim to apply haptic devices to emulate the mechanical response characteristics of a rubber material. The long term aim is to develop a haptic demonstration platform that allows students to explore the select change of molecular characteristics (such as crosslink density or density on ‘dangling chains’) as well as temperature or degree of swelling on the mechanical response of a rubber during a tensile stress-strain deformation experiment. In collaboration with Denny Wu (an Undergraduate student in the departments of Materials Science and Engineering as well as Biology) we completed a Matlab based interface that can be connected to a Falcon Force Feedback joystick. We successfully demonstrated a linear load-displacement response using the device.
